title: Probate california
question: The final court date for the estate in probate is july 22, there are no debts owed, etc. according to the probate notes area of the court website everything has been submitted properly. My question is when can the cash assets be distributed? When I asked this to the attorney handeling the estate my response was "who the hell knows how long it will sit on the judges desk after the court hearing". From all the information I've been able to gather the cash assets should be able to be distributed immediately. If not what is it that we'd be waiting for?
answers:
An accounting and petition for distribution must be made before you are allowed to distribute from a probate estate. This allows the beneficiaries and the court to "check you work" as the estate fiduciary. Once you are approved by the court, then distribute away, just make sure that you, with your counsel, explain what your distribution plan is, so that the court can approve the methodology as well. This is important, as your methodology can by challanged just as easily as the amounts. With court approval, you are insulated from such potential liability.

At the hearing, the court will need to "approve" the Petition for Distribution, including the requests for administrative and attorneys fees; once approved, your attorney must submit a proposed Order for Final Distribution (and approval of the included accounting if not waived by all beneficiaries) and then once that Order is signed by the court, the money can be distributed.

Disclaimer: This information is not intended as legal advise. You should consult with a California attorney with your specific details before making any decisions or taking any action.

Generally, it is best to obtain a conformed (with the court stamp and Judge's signature) copy of the Order allowing you to distribute the assets of the estate BEFORE you distribute. Until you have that order, you don't know if the court has made any changes to the distribution. Better to be safe than sorry. If you are in a hurry, you can go down to the court to obtain a copy, or mail a request to the court for a copy. If you have an attorney working on the probate with you, then just call the attorney until they send you a copy.
